Decorators

  • since 0.1
  • targets Swift

By now you should have a good feel for the Sempiler goals and design principles. You might be wondering why we favor fakeywords over decorators, and whether we use decorators at all.

Sempiler does support decorators but in some languages they are limited to method and declarations only (not even constructors). The decision on whether to opt for decorators over fakeywords is based on the constraints of the source language.

We need to use our augmented set of keywords for variable types, return types and other situations. In a source language like TypeScript this would not be possible with decorators.

Semantic transpilation is agnostic of any particular source language or target context

Struct

Declaring a struct is implemented using a decorator because the only valid usage for it is on a class-like declaration.

Classes and structs are closely aligned semantically and so utilising a standard class-like declaration to express either construct feels like a low friction, comfortable solution.

Platform Specific

Decorators are extensible in Sempiler and can be provided on a platform specific basis. For example, concepts like UIApplicationMain in iOS are implemented using a decorator in Sempiler because it is only valid on a class-like declaration.

Target platforms will declare the applicable contextual decorators in their respective core stub APIs.
